title.narrative: WFP & FAO - Resilience project in North and South Ubangi, DRC
WFP & FAO - Resiliens i Nord och Sydubangi, DRK

description.narrative:
FN:s livsmedelsprogram (WFP) har i samarbete med FN:s livsmedels- och jordbruksorganisation (FAO) ansökt till Sida om finansiellt stöd om 65 miljoner svenska kronor för att genomföra programmet "Fostering resilience and sustainable livelihood systems in North and South Ubangi" under perioden 2020-2023.
Befolkningen i Nord och Syd Ubangi i västra DRK är till stor del beroende av jordbruksproduktion för sin överlevnad. Uppskattningsvis kommer över 60 % av maten som konsumeras från småskalig jordbruksproduktion. Provinsen är egentligen mycket bördig, men av olika anledningar är produktionen inom jordbruket mycket låg och faktum är att 78 % av hushållen i Sydubangi och 59% i Nordubangi räknas om matosäkra (food insecure) vilket är över det nationella snittet i DRK. Området har också tagit emot ett stort antal flyktingar från Central Afrikanska Republiken. Dessa flyktingar bor till stor del utanför flyktingläger och livnär sig på samma mark som lokalbefolkningen. Detta skapar ofta konflikt mellan befolkningsgrupper som gör det svårt att hitta långsiktiga, hållbara lösningar för flyktingarna. Området har en bristande infrastruktur, jordbrukare har inga eller dåliga möjligheter att förädla sin produktion, bristande tillgång till marknader samt ingen eller dålig tillgång till krediter. Cirka 38% av DRKs undernärda befolkning äter en ensidig kost i form av kasava trots att faktiska förutsättningar för en bredare produktion föreligger.
Det föreslagna gemensamma FN programmet "Fostering resilience and sustainable livelihood systems in North and South Ubangi " har som övergripande målsättning, givet den utvecklingsproblematik som beskrivs ovan, att:
1. Minska mat och nutritions behov för sårbara hushåll 2. Öka småskaliga jordbrukares tekniska och finansiella kapacitet att öka sin jordbruksproduktion, samt att förbättra deras tillgång till marknader. Detta kommer att innebära ökade inkomster och försörjningsmöjligheter och gör dem mer resilienta mot framtida chocker. 3. Stödja lokala organisationer så de bidrar aktivt till social sammanhållning, jämställdhet, fred och försoning.
Programmet avser att bidra till ovanstående målsättningar genom att uppnå följande resultat:
1) Lokala organisationer har förbättrat kapaciteten för hållbar och näringskänslig livsmedelsproduktion samt förbättrad kapacitet att bedriva en uthållig jordbruksproduktion, optimerad hantering av skörd, raffinera livsmedel ur sin skörd samt öka sin tillgång till marknader.
2) Samhällena har kapacitet att arbeta konfliktförebyggande samt att främja social sammanhållning, jämställdhet, fred och försoning.
3) Kvinnors status, levnadsförhållande och faktiska beslutanderätt har stärkts som ett direkt resultat av programmet.
4) Hushåll på landsbygden får tillgång till finansiellt stöd genom att de bidrar till förbättring av infrastruktur i form av vägbygge och liknande projekt samt etablerandet av samhällsbaserade låntagarorganisationer.
De direkta mottagarna av det stöd som insatsen kommer att generera är 13 000 hushåll, varav 5 000 i Libengedisktriktet, 4 000 i Gemenadisktriktet och 4 000 i Mobay Mbongodistriktet. De nämnda distrikten ligger belägna i Ubangiprovinserna i västra DRK.
Programmets totala budget är på 65 miljoner svenska kronor för 2020 - 2023. WFP:s del i budgeten är 57 procent och FAO:s del i budgeten är 43 procent.
WFP kommer att vara Sveriges avtalspart genom undertecknandet av ett insatsavtal. En standardmall som tagits fram av FN:s utvecklingsgrupp (UNDG), en sk. Standard Administrative Arrangement för pass-through fund management för gemensamma program (SAA), kommer att användas (Mallen är fastställd genom Sida beslut 2015-003649). Administrative Agent (administrativt ansvarig) är WFP, de undertecknar SAA med Sverige representerat av Sida och administrerar de medel som tillställs programmet. De ansvarar för att sammanställa den finansiella rapporteringen från de Deltagande FN-organen (Participating UN Organizations). För att utföra detta arbete har WFP rätt att ta ut en administrativ avgift på 1 procent. WFP är också sk. Convening Agent (sammankallande) vilket innebär att WFP har ansvar för att koordinera den narrativa rapporteringen av programmet. Både FAO och WFP är också Deltagande FN-organ, sk. Partcipating UN Organizations vilket innebär att de kommer implementera programmet. Deltagande FN organ har rätt till att ta 7 % i avgift för att täcka deras indirekta kostnader relaterade till implementeringen av programmet. WFP tar i detta sammanhanget 6.5% enligt beslut på deras huvudkontor.
Till SAA kommer att biläggas en kopia för information av ett signerat ”Memorandum of Understanding” (MoU) upprättat specifikt för programmet mellan de Deltagande FN-organen, Administrative Agent och Convening Agent, dvs. WFP och FAO, där deras inbördes ansvar anges (detta MoU görs inte till avtalsinnehåll).
Det är Sidas, WFPs och FAOs avsikt att samordna med andra givare så mycket som möjligt. Genom att samarbeta med Kanada och Tyskland kan administrationen kring rapportering effektiviseras.

The World Food Programme (WFP) and the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) has submitted a project proposal to Sida for 65 million Swedish crowns (SEK) to implement a three year programme titled "Fostering resilience and sustainable livelihood systems in North and South Ubangi" for the period 2020-2023.
The population in North and South Ubangi I western DRC is largely dependent on agriculture for their survival. Approximately 60% of the food consumed come from small scale, local farmers. The province is made up of fertile land yet 78% of the households in South Ubangi are defined as food insecure and 59% of the households in North Ubangi are deemed food insecure. This is above the national average.
The province has also received a large number of refugees from the Central African Republic. The refugees live within the host communities and not in camps. This means that they are dependent on farming the same land which can be cause for conflict and cohesion issues in some locations which makes it difficult to move refugees off humanitarian aid and provide durable solutions for income generation and local integration.
Despite the agricultural potential and forest resources, there is a widespread chronic poverty and a lack of knowledge about the province's nutritional potential through agriculture, livestock and fisheries. Poor purchasing power has limited access to food by poor groups. This resulted in poor consumption and in the deterioration of livelihoods relying on low food value. Reduced quantities of food and limited intake of diversified foods has resulted in a high rate of malnutrition. More than 38% of the population facing chronic malnutrition, due to a diet that is often unbalanced and dominated by staple foods especially cassava.
The Provinces are characterized by poor or inexistent infrastructure with poor road conditions resulting in the lack of an efficient and effective transportation system and crippling the performance of small-scale farmers. The isolation limits access to market facilities and impedes vibrant markets and commerce to take root in rural areas, causing unstable prices which are dependent on availability of food.
The proposed project ”Fostering resilience and sustainable livelihood systems in North and South Ubangi " has the following overarching objectives:
1. To address food and nutrition needs of vulnerable households; 2. To increase smallholder farmers’ agricultural and financial capacities for sustainable production and market engagement to increase their incomes and build resilient livelihoods; 3. To reduce the disparities between women and men in the targeted territories and support social cohesion and peace.
The programme aims to achieve the above objectives through the following outcomes and outputs:
1. Community based organizations have improved capacities on sustainable and nutrition sensitive food production, processing and commercialization
Output 1.1: Targeted community-based organizations have strengthened their local governance and structure in a gender sensitive manner
Output 1.2: Targeted households have received support and capacity development on sustainable and nutrition sensitive agricultural production and food processing
Output 1.3: Targeted households are trained in post-harvest management and commercialization
2. Beneficiary communities are prepared to take action for the promotion of social cohesion, and peaceful cohabitation among refugees and host communities
Output 2.1: Refugees and Host communities have improved social cohesion at community level
Output 2.2.: Early warning and conflict prevention systems are established to promote diversity, peace and social cohesion between refugees and host communities
3. Women’s status/conditions in their communities have improved and gender equality is strengthened thanks to the project activities.
Output 3.1: Targeted women have received training to improve leadership and decision making skills in community based organizations
Output 3.2: Targeted women have improved access to diversified income sources
Output 3.3: Communities are trained and supported on safe access to fuel and energy
4. Targeted households have improved access to inclusive financing and productive Community assets
Output 4.1: Vulnerable households, including refugees have received support through social safety nets to rehabilitate Priority community productive assets
Output 4.2: Community Saving and Loans associations have been established
The direct beneficiaries of the intervention are 13 000 households of which 5 000 are located in Libenge, 4 000 in Gemena and 4 000 in Mobay Mbongo. The districts are all located in North and South Ubangi in western DRC and totals 78 000 individuals.
The total budget for the project proposal is 65 million SEK for 2020 - 2023. WFPs portion of the budget is 57 percent and FAO:s portion is 43 percent. WFP will enter into agreement with the Swedish Embassy. A standard UNDG template for Standard Administrative Arrangement for pass-through fund management for join programs (SAA) will be used. This template was agreed upon through Sida decision number 2015-003649.
WFP is the Administrative Agent who will collect all contributions from Sweden as the donor. WFP will keep and allocate the funds on the basis of requests according to established guidelines and routines. The UNDG guidelines are used.
WFP is the Convening Agent and convenes all parties as necessary. FAO is the Participating Agency with regard to all agriculture and food value chain interventions. Each of the organisations will manage their contributions in accordance with their respective rules and routines as set out in their respective accountability frameworks. WFP as the administrative agent is not accountable towards the donor for FAO's implementation, spending and fund management.
All allocations are made in accordance with the project document and the allocated time line. They are based on follow up and an anlysis of progress made to date. Allocations are made from the donor to WFP based on payment requests and from WFP to partners based on payment requests.
In the case of a pass-through agreement (as described above), the common ISC rate (7%) will apply for FAO, while WFP will receive 6.5% as per corporate rules. The managing agency (WFP in this case) will also apply a 1% management fee (for the management of the agreement between the two agencies).
A memorandum of understanding (MoU) between WFP and FAO will be attached to the SAA. This will outline the roles of the adminstrative, participating and convening agents.
It is Sidas, WFPs and FAOs intention to coordinate as much as possible for other donors, Germany and Canada, to ensure that duplications in reporting are avoided and efficiency gains are made.

To address food and nutrition needs of vulnerable households. 1. To address food and nutrition needs of vulnerable households; 2. To increase smallholder farmers’ agricultural and financial capacities for sustainable production and market engagement in order to increase their incomes and build resilient livelihoods; 3. To reduce the disparities between women and men in the targeted territories and support social cohesion and peace;
The practical elements of the intervention are described below, these are an indication of how change will be achieved. These activities have been tested in multiple settings with proven good results. Help farmers and farmer cooperatives from host communities and refugees to raise their food production and therefore also increase their income, reduce debt burdens in times of crisis and ensure sustainable food and nutrition security. The combined strategic efforts to build resilience and generate incomes will contribute to increase social cohesion between refugees and host communities and will open doors for development and exit strategies for refugee’s assistance. Attention will be given to improve the adoption of innovative good practices such as the use of bio-fertilizers and improved seeds to improve productivity. These techniques will be promoted through a participatory learning by doing approach called “Farmer Field Schools”. These trainings will also promote the safe and correct use of organic and mineral fertilizers in terms of amounts, timing and methods appropriate to agronomic, environmental and human health requirements. Asset Creation will contribute to constructing feeder roads, storage infrastructure and reforestation. At the same time these activities will promote social and economic integration. Livelihood opportunities for women and youth will be increased. By focusing on a Food/cash-for-Assets approach, the project is fostering a shift from dependency on food aid to sustainable livelihoods. In addition, investment will be made in pre-and post-harvest technologies to improve food security by reducing food losses and thereby increasing the amount of food available for consumption by farmers and poor rural and urban consumers. The project will include a robust financial component. A community-based saving and loans initiative will be implemented with the aim of facilitating beneficiaries’ access to rural finance opportunities as a means of durable resilience. The basic principle of the VSLA in this project is that targeted farmer groups of the project form a Village Saving and Loan Association: a group of people who save together and take small loans from savings to invest in their livelihoods. A conditional cash transfer might be given to groups demonstrate their engagement, so they can profit from increased capital for credits and investments in their livelihoods. For women only groups, complementary interventions will be organized on income generating activities to diversify income sources. To mitigate the negative impact the collection of firewood is having on the environment the project will distribute improved cooking stoves. When cooking fuel is not readily available, it can have a considerable impact on the nutrition of vulnerable populations. On the other hand, the time women spend collecting fuelwood directly affects the time available for caring and feeding of children with possible negative impacts on nutrition. The collection of firewood is also directly linked to increased risk of gender-based and sexual violence as women have to walk long distances in insecure areas. The project will involve women in all aspects of the value chain with a strengthened role in decision making.

description.narrative: 2020 was the second year of implementation of the Resilience Programme in and after all the preparations that took place in 2019 where in place some clear results were demonstrated. In a country suffering from poor infrastructure, rehabilitation of agricultural feeder roads is essential and in 2020 WFP supported the rehabilitation of basic community assets. Road infrastructure was completed in the territories of Libenge, Gemena and Mobayi Mbongo. Food assistance addresses the immediate needs of the most vulnerable, while asset creation builds community livelihoods and resilience over the medium to long term. The food for assets component of this programme which contributes to the building of roads is an important component as it addresses problems identified in the agricultural value chains. WFP and FAO have developed a joint strategy for building infrastructure that provides solutions for Farmer Organisations to link food production to markets. This includes construction of 397 km of road in Libenge; 630 km in Gemena and 135 km in Mobayi Mbongo. Special attention is paid to agricultural feeder roads as these roads facilitate access to areas of high agricultural production and lead to markets or major consumption centres. In addition to this construction the following activities have been implemented. * The registration of the 13,000 beneficiary households in WFP’s beneficiary management platform, SCOPE. * Functional literacy and activities to promote gender equality * Raising awareness on social cohesion and peaceful coexistence * WFP has also provided conditional cash and/or food distributions to support rural savings activities through Village Savings and Credit Associations (VSCAs). With regard to the agriculture component of FAO results were achieved with regard to seed production. Due to the presence of various agricultural projects in the intervention area, Ubangi has potential for seed operators. FAO has identified 18 agri-multipliers approved by the national seed service (SENASEM), including 12 in the South and 7 in North Ubangi. These agri-multipliers support the multiplication of basic seeds making quality basic seeds available in the intervention areas and thereby offsetting the degeneration of seed varieties which, in turn, will increase agricultural production in quantity and quality. To prepare for the 2020 agricultural season, FAO acquired the basic seeds from INERA and distributed them to: 12 agro-multipliers in Gemena and Libenge: * 11.86 tons of food crop seeds (maize, groundnut, cowpeas and rice) * 7,500 linear metres of cassava, to produce on about 300 ha. 7 agri-multipliers in the Mobayi-Mbongo area: * 4.96 tonnes of food crop seeds (maize, groundnut, cowpea and rice) * 2,500 linear metres of cassava to produce on about 125 ha. SENASEM's mission is to control and certify quality seeds produced in DRC which has also been done in the context of this programme. SENASEM has validated the quality and certified that the seeds produced by the agro-multipliers involved and identified comply with the standards established in the country. In addition to this construction the following activities have been implemented. * Structuring of households into Farmer Organizations and Unions of Farmer Organizations (UFO), and organization of Farmer Field Schools (FFS) * Capacity building in post-harvest management
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
